unnormalised: It’s been almost a year since my sister, Priya, started facing issues with her in-laws. Initially, it was small things – comments about her cooking (even though she works a demanding job as a software engineer in TCS), or subtle digs about her family’s financial status. But things escalated quickly.
normalised: It's been almost a year since my sister, Priya, started facing issues with her in-laws. Initially, it was small things – comments about her cooking (even though she works a demanding job as a software engineer in T-C-S), or subtle digs about her family's financial status. But things escalated quickly.

unnormalised: Priya had always dreamt of a happy married life, a family just like the Bollywood movies portrayed. Instead, she found herself trapped in a constant battle of wills. Her husband, Rohan, initially tried to mediate, but the pressure from his family was immense. He started siding with them more often than not, further isolating Priya.

unnormalised: The final straw came a few months back. An argument over jewellery during Diwali celebrations led to a full-blown confrontation. Priya was verbally abused and even locked in her room for several hours. That’s when she decided enough was enough.

unnormalised: She contacted Adv. Mehra, a renowned family lawyer, after a sleepless night and a lot of tears. I remember her telling me, “I can’t live like this anymore, di. I need help.” That marked the beginning of our journey through the confusing and often heartbreaking world of family law in India.

I need help.” That marked the beginning of our journey through the confusing and often heartbreaking world of family law in India.

unnormalised: The initial consultation with Adv. Mehra was overwhelming. She explained the various options available to Priya: Section 498A of the IPC (Indian Penal Code) for domestic violence, divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, and claims for maintenance under Section 125 of the CrPC (Criminal Procedure Code). It felt like learning a new language, filled with acronyms and legal jargon.
normalised: The initial consultation with A-D-V. Mehra was overwhelming. She explained the various options available to Priya: Section four hundred and ninety eight A of the I-P-C (Indian Penal Code) for domestic violence, divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty five, and claims for maintenance under Section one hundred and twenty five of the C-R-P-C (Criminal Procedure Code). It felt like learning a new language, filled with acronyms and legal jargon.

unnormalised: The process has been long and arduous. Filing the FIR (First Information Report) was a traumatic experience. Dealing with the police, navigating the court system, and attending hearings has taken a toll on Priya's mental health. She has had to take leaves from work for weeks on end. Rohan's family filed for anticipatory bail and got it on 21/07/2023.
normalised: The process has been long and arduous. Filing the F-I-R (First Information Report) was a traumatic experience. Dealing with the police, navigating the court system, and attending hearings has taken a toll on Priya's mental health. She has had to take leaves from work for weeks on end. Rohan's family filed for anticipatory bail and got it on twenty first July two thousand and twenty three.

unnormalised: One of the biggest challenges has been the societal stigma associated with divorce. People, especially those in our extended family, have been quick to judge and offer unsolicited advice. “Try to adjust,” they say, or “Think about your reputation.” But Priya is determined to build a life of dignity and respect for herself.

unnormalised: The case is still ongoing. We’re hoping for a fair resolution, one that allows Priya to move on and rebuild her life. We even discussed the possibility of mediation with the help of NGO workers, though the other side seems reluctant for it.

unnormalised: This whole experience has been a wake-up call for me. It’s made me realize how important it is for women to know their rights and have the courage to stand up for themselves, even when faced with overwhelming odds. Perhaps, by sharing Priya's story, we can empower other women to seek help when they need it.
